episode_summary: This episode covers Seymour Cray’s supercomputing and eccentric habits, the origin of the crane (machine) being named after the bird, the science of silica gel, and Mary Somerville’s pioneering role and the exclusion of women from scientific institutions. Along the way they detour through PS3 supercomputers, medieval treadwheel cranes, opals and graphene, and historical scientific anecdotes.

facts.fact: Okay, my fat this week is that when the father of supercomputing Seymour Kray got stuck on a problem, he would go into tunnels, he built under his house and speak to elves.
My fact is that a crane is called a crane because it looks like a crane.
My question is, a single gram of silica gel has an area of 800 square meters.
My fact this week is that the first female scientist to be celebrated with a marble bust at the Royal Society was never able to visit it because women weren't allowed in the building.
